title: Evidence-Grounded Tutoring Scope
text: This tutor answers questions using course snippets (KB doc ids) and lab artifacts. When evidence is missing, request specific headers/log lines rather than guessing.

title: Recognizing Phishing Emails
text: Phishing emails often use urgent language, unexpected attachments, or mismatched sender domains. Check headers and verify links before clicking.

title: Sender Spoofing and Domain Mismatch
text: The visible From name/address can be spoofed. Compare the sender domain to the organizationâ€™s real domain, inspect Reply-To/Return-Path, and review Received hops for the originating IP/domain.

title: Suspicious Links and URL Inspection
text: Before clicking, hover to inspect the destination, look for punycode or typosquatting, and verify via a trusted channel (official website or phone).

title: Attachments and Macros
text: Malicious documents may use macros (e.g., .docm) to execute code. Treat unexpected invoices/resumes as suspicious and use sandboxing/AV scanning before opening.

title: Lateral Movement Overview
text: Lateral movement involves pivoting within a compromised network using credentials or exploitation of internal services. Typical indicators include unusual SMB activity and privileged credential use.

title: Credential Reuse and NTLM/Pass-the-Hash
text: Attackers may reuse stolen credentials or NTLM hashes to authenticate to other hosts. Watch for new logons with service accounts, off-hours activity, and repeated authentication failures/successes across hosts.

title: Remote Execution via SMB/WMI/PsExec
text: Remote services (SMB admin shares, WMI, PsExec, scheduled tasks) are commonly used for lateral movement. Indicators include remote service creation, admin share access, and process creation tied to remote management tools.

title: Privilege Escalation Basics
text: Privilege escalation increases access (e.g., from user to admin). Common signals include new admin group membership, suspicious credential dumping attempts, or unexpected use of privileged tokens.

title: Data Exfiltration and Staging
text: Exfiltration may involve compressing/staging data, then transferring via HTTPS/DNS/SMB or cloud services. Indicators include unusual outbound connections, large transfers, or new archives created on sensitive hosts.

title: Incident Response: First Actions
text: Start by preserving evidence, scoping affected accounts/hosts, and containing risk (e.g., isolate host, reset credentials). Document what you observed and which artifacts support each claim.
